sections.title: Landlord Entry Requirements
sections.text: Landlords must provide reasonable notice before entering a rental unit, typically 24-48 hours. Entry must be for a legitimate purpose (repairs, inspections, showings). Entry without notice or at unreasonable times may violate tenant privacy rights under New York law.

sections.title: Security Deposit Requirements
sections.text: In New York, security deposits must be refundable and returned within a reasonable time after lease termination. For rent-stabilized units, deposits are limited. Landlords must provide itemized deductions and cannot make deposits 'non-refundable' or exercise unilateral discretion over returns.

sections.title: Rent Stabilization Protections
sections.text: In New York City and other jurisdictions, rent-stabilized tenants have protections against excessive rent increases, eviction without just cause, and lease renewal rights. Landlords cannot circumvent these protections through lease terms.

sections.title: Warranty of Habitability
sections.text: Landlords must maintain rental units in habitable condition with working heat, hot water, plumbing, and compliance with housing codes. Tenants may withhold rent or file complaints with HPD if landlords fail to make necessary repairs. Essential repairs cannot be shifted to tenants.
